awd_titl_txt: Type II: UCF I-Corps Site - enhancing technology commercialization to develop a world-class innovation ecosystem
awd_abstract_narration:
This project extends the University of Central Florida's (UCF) I-Corps Site for an additional three years beyond their initial three-year award. NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors. There are two types of I-Corps Site proposals. Type I proposals are submitted by institutions that have not had prior funding as an I-Corps Site. These proposals may request $100,000 per year for up to five years. Type II proposals are submitted by institutions that have had prior funding as an I-Corps Site. These proposals may request up to $100,000 per year for up to three years. 

The intellectual merits of the I-Corps Site renewal project at UCF include the capture and curation of a deep understanding of (1) the processes, methodologies and programs for entrepreneurship education and technology commercialization, (2) Best practices for transitioning research from the bench top into the marketplace, (3) and distributing this knowledge to collaborators, partners, and affiliates throughout the NIN, and (4) development and adaptation of programs for specialty cohorts supporting local clusters and targeted populations. Additional knowledge and understanding will be gained through the collection of longitudinal data following I-Corps participants after they have completed the curriculum. 

UCF is an active and engaged partner in the Central Florida innovation ecosystem. The broader impacts from this project directly contribute to the broader community understanding of innovation-based economic development and the importance of research and commercialization. This is critically important to a community that is dependent on tourism and hospitality and the associated lower paying jobs in the region. Building on the initial successes of the UCF I-Corps Site program, successful commercialization of research and inventions generated at the leading research institutions and affiliate organizations in the region, this renewal project has the potential to significantly impact the regional economy. Further, with curriculum that effectively serves Hispanic populations, there is the potential to produce major social and economic impact on a national level. Florida has the third largest Hispanic population in the U.S., with nearly 25% of UCF student population and 34% of Florida business owners being of Hispanic origin, making this an ideal location to develop, deploy, and refine the curriculum.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES

por.por_cntn:
Project outcomes

 

The NSF I-Corps program has been transformative for UCF, the greater Orlando region and the State of Florida.  It has put a spotlight on innovation based economic development, showcased the need for diversification of a regional economy and provided a proven process to assist communities looking to improve the overall economic prosperity of a region.

It has created a methodology, provided a common vocabulary, and helped universities understand the importance of supporting startups in a smart, self-enlightened way.  It reduces the risks associated with tech transfer and helps inventors better understand the true value of their intellectual capital.  It has attracted many community entrepreneurs to the university community that serve as mentors and coaches to these teams.  Some form long term relationships with he team members.

As a result of UCF and USF’s site programs, the Florida Board of Governors for the State Universities of Florida has included number of I-Corps teams each year as a metric in it’s annual report.  This action provides a great incentive for University’s in Florida to make this a continued high priority. This annual report from the President’s office of each university has brought attention to the efforts statewide elevating the stature of the program.

Central Florida’s innovation ecosystem has evolved and been widely supported by UCF’s I-Corps. The following are noteworthy successes and achievements that have occurred since the inception of the I-Corps Site project.

  • UCF’s I-Corps participants are diverse, 19% have been female and 34% have been under-represented minorities. Of the Entrepreneurial Leads, 26% have been female and 39% have been under-represented minorities. Of the PIs, 21% have been female and 39% have been under-represented minorities.
  • We have had more than 10% apply or are in the process of applying to the National I-Corps, and more than 10 have been accepted and participated in National I-Corps. This includes one team from the cohort with FIU that was selected and participated in the National I-Corps program in the Summer of 2016. 
  • Within UCF, I-Corps is now a required element in the Career Advancement Mentoring Program for Young Entrepreneurs and Scholars (CAMP-YES) that prepares academically talented, financially challenged junior and senior STEM students to successfully transition to the workforce, graduate school, or create a start-up venture upon completion of a baccalaureate degree in a STEM discipline[i].
  • I-Corps curriculum has also been integrated as a required element of eli2, and the Technology Entrepreneurship graduate course, and has become the standard methodology used in the Blackstone Launchpad and UCFBIP programs.
  • UCF I-Corps Alumni have earned more than $2.5 million in funding, of which $450,000 is grant funding. Collectively, they have sought nearly 200 grant opportunities with the support of the UCF programs, exclusively licensed 18 patents from UCF’s OTT, and achieved 38 founded or co-founded ventures based on research. Starter Studio, UCF I-Corps’ community partner, has trained 31 teams in the I-Corps methodology
  • The NSF I-Corps curriculum has been introduced across campus in for credits and not for credit venues.  In the Industrial Engineering capstone class, a 7-week program is incorporated into the course.  The Master program in Data Analytics delivers a full 10 week program covering both the right and left hand sides of the Business Model Canvas. 
  • Lean Startup Orlando was formed to share lean methods region-wide and bring in guest speakers to practitioners.
  • The University Tech Ventures Symposium (UTVS) was created by I-Corps instructors and staff to provides a showcase of UCF Innovations.  These hidden gems as they were called, are introduced to an extended community of students, faculty, alumni, venture investors, entrepreneurs, innovators, community leaders and other interested stakeholders. An introduction to I-Corps is always on the agenda.

 

UCF has coached 184 teams through the I-Corps program.  Many of these teams have done well post I-Corps.  Some have gone on to the National I-Corps program, some have secured SBIR or other government awards and some have secured traditional investment.  The NSF I-Corps program at UCF has produced many great stories. 

These outcomes are especially important to communities, such as Orlando, with an overdependence of one industry sector such as hospitality, tourism, and entertainment. The NSF I-Corps is a program provides a tangible methodology for diversifying a regional economy.


[i] https://campyes.cecs.ucf.edu/

 


Last Modified: 02/28/2023
Modified by: Thomas O'neal
por.por_txt_cntn:
Project outcomes

 

The NSF I-Corps program has been transformative for UCF, the greater Orlando region and the State of Florida.  It has put a spotlight on innovation based economic development, showcased the need for diversification of a regional economy and provided a proven process to assist communities looking to improve the overall economic prosperity of a region.

It has created a methodology, provided a common vocabulary, and helped universities understand the importance of supporting startups in a smart, self-enlightened way.  It reduces the risks associated with tech transfer and helps inventors better understand the true value of their intellectual capital.  It has attracted many community entrepreneurs to the university community that serve as mentors and coaches to these teams.  Some form long term relationships with he team members.

As a result of UCF and USF’s site programs, the Florida Board of Governors for the State Universities of Florida has included number of I-Corps teams each year as a metric in it’s annual report.  This action provides a great incentive for University’s in Florida to make this a continued high priority. This annual report from the President’s office of each university has brought attention to the efforts statewide elevating the stature of the program.

Central Florida’s innovation ecosystem has evolved and been widely supported by UCF’s I-Corps. The following are noteworthy successes and achievements that have occurred since the inception of the I-Corps Site project.

UCF’s I-Corps participants are diverse, 19% have been female and 34% have been under-represented minorities. Of the Entrepreneurial Leads, 26% have been female and 39% have been under-represented minorities. Of the PIs, 21% have been female and 39% have been under-represented minorities. 
We have had more than 10% apply or are in the process of applying to the National I-Corps, and more than 10 have been accepted and participated in National I-Corps. This includes one team from the cohort with FIU that was selected and participated in the National I-Corps program in the Summer of 2016.  
Within UCF, I-Corps is now a required element in the Career Advancement Mentoring Program for Young Entrepreneurs and Scholars (CAMP-YES) that prepares academically talented, financially challenged junior and senior STEM students to successfully transition to the workforce, graduate school, or create a start-up venture upon completion of a baccalaureate degree in a STEM discipline[i]. 
I-Corps curriculum has also been integrated as a required element of eli2, and the Technology Entrepreneurship graduate course, and has become the standard methodology used in the Blackstone Launchpad and UCFBIP programs.
UCF I-Corps Alumni have earned more than $2.5 million in funding, of which $450,000 is grant funding. Collectively, they have sought nearly 200 grant opportunities with the support of the UCF programs, exclusively licensed 18 patents from UCF’s OTT, and achieved 38 founded or co-founded ventures based on research. Starter Studio, UCF I-Corps’ community partner, has trained 31 teams in the I-Corps methodology 
The NSF I-Corps curriculum has been introduced across campus in for credits and not for credit venues.  In the Industrial Engineering capstone class, a 7-week program is incorporated into the course.  The Master program in Data Analytics delivers a full 10 week program covering both the right and left hand sides of the Business Model Canvas.  
Lean Startup Orlando was formed to share lean methods region-wide and bring in guest speakers to practitioners.
The University Tech Ventures Symposium (UTVS) was created by I-Corps instructors and staff to provides a showcase of UCF Innovations.  These hidden gems as they were called, are introduced to an extended community of students, faculty, alumni, venture investors, entrepreneurs, innovators, community leaders and other interested stakeholders. An introduction to I-Corps is always on the agenda.


 

UCF has coached 184 teams through the I-Corps program.  Many of these teams have done well post I-Corps.  Some have gone on to the National I-Corps program, some have secured SBIR or other government awards and some have secured traditional investment.  The NSF I-Corps program at UCF has produced many great stories. 

These outcomes are especially important to communities, such as Orlando, with an overdependence of one industry sector such as hospitality, tourism, and entertainment. The NSF I-Corps is a program provides a tangible methodology for diversifying a regional economy.

 



[i] https://campyes.cecs.ucf.edu/
